loans.use: To buy more fruit for re-sale

loans.name: Omina

texts.en:
I. Omina is 45 years old. She married and the mother of four children. Her husband is a taxi driver. In order to support her husband with the family expenses, Omina has been running her own business of selling coats and jackets at the local market of Isfara town for more than 12 years.

She started with a small side business from home. Thanks to her good nature, she has been able to multiply her client base. Her main motivation is to provide a good education for her four children and to make their family living conditions better. Omina already has a good fixed client base, whose buying changes with the seasons. Since autumn came, she is certain she will take in good sales.

Omina is requesting a loan of 3400 Somoni (1000 USD) to purchase autumn raincoats, since she knows her demand is increasing and already has orders for them. She plans to repay the loan within 8 months. She is grateful for your support in continuing her business and helping improve her family's quality of life. We believe Omina’s willingness to offer her customers greater value and a wider choice of merchandise, combined with her excellent service, will secure the successful growth of her trade and guarantee good profits from sales.

loans.use: Purchase autumn coats for women in order to increase her range of goods.

loans.name: Song

texts.en:
Song L., 48, is a professional tailor who lives with three of her four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 

Since 2005, she has been a tailor to earn a living and is able to make around US$2 of profit per day. She is aided by one of her children, who works as a garment factory worker. Her husband, Sreng Chheang, 52, is a motorbike mechanic. On average, he earns US$2 of profit per day.

Mrs. Song would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of US$500 to purchase more cloth for her business and also add one more sewing machine. (Mr. Sreng is pictured because Mrs. Song was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more cloth for her business and also add one more sewing machine.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tuti

texts.en:
Tuti K. is 40 years old. She is married with 2 children. The need for an extra income was what pushed Tuti to start selling coats and jackets, seeing as her husband does not have a good income. Her primary concern is to be able to provide her children with the education they require to be able to have a future with dignified quality of life.

It has already been 15 years since she started her business, and thanks to the unconditional support of her own and the love of her family, she has been able to continue until now.

Tuti now requires a loan of 3400 Somoni (1000 USD) that will be used to purchase merchandise that her clients have asked for, as she does not have the needed capital to increase her selection. She plans to repay the full amount of her loan in 8 months. Don’t doubt it! Help Tuti to continue moving forward and help her dreams to become reality, to provide her children with the education they need. They will thank you forever.

loans.use: Purchasing autumn coats for women to increase her range of goods

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is 42 years old. She is married. She has been a khanga seller since 2004. Every day she works at her business.

Fatma now requests a loan to buy more khanga for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cloth (khanga) for her business

loans.name: Salima

texts.en:
Salima M. is 42 years old. She is a very wise and hard-working woman. She is married, with three children. The children attend the public school of the town. This entrepreneur dedicates herself to the sale of shoes for men and women. Salima admits that lending services from IMON have helped her business grow over the past 8 years.

Little by little, she has expanded her inventory and thanks to the good service she offers, her business is growing rapidly. She says that with income from her business she is able to provide education and food for her children.

Now Salima needs a loan of 2000 Somoni which she will use to buy merchandise to meet the demand of her clients and to continue growing her business. She is committed to paying back this loan in 3 months. This is the time to help someone who needs it. Please do not hesitate to help improve the quality of life of this family.

loans.use: Purchasing autumn shoes for men and women for re-sale

loans.name: Zamzam's Muamini Mungu Group

texts.en:
Zamzam is a widow with 3 children, aged between 32 and 24. She has been a firewood, clothing, and food seller since 1993. Every day she works from 6:00 AM to 3:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Zamzam now requests a loan to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with selling food, clothing, and decorations.

loans.use: To improve her business by increasing her current stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Zahida

texts.en:
Zahida bjai is the wife of M. S. and lives in an area named Yadgar (a famous historical place) in Lahore, Pakistan. She has lived in Yadgar for the last 4 years. She has five children: three girls and two boys. Her elder son is married. Her younger son has a milk shop where he sells milk from his own buffaloes. Her daughters completed their education until the 10th standard. Now they are in an age of marriage.

Zahida baji's husband sells plastic utensils in different areas of Lahore. Zahida baji has a livestock business. She takes care of her buffaloes as if they were her own children. She gets up early in the morning to milk them and to give them food. Her monthly income is $394. Zahida baji is very happy because last week one of her buffalo gave birth to a calf. She is applying for a loan to expand her livestock business and to expand her son's milk business.

loans.use: Buy another buffalo to expand milk production

loans.name: Amina's Kisonge Daima Group

texts.en:
Amina is 32 years. She is married with 2 children, 13 and 10 years old. She has been a clothes and shoe seller since 2004. Everyday she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Amina now requests a loan to buy more clothes and shoes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Semeni, who also has a business of selling clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Lorng

texts.en: Mrs. Lorng C., who is 24 years old, is a pig raiser; her husband, Mr. Thorn Thav, makes wine and drives a motorcycle taxi. Lorng has two children, both of whom live in the family's home and are in school. Now her pig business is going well and she needs to fatten her pigs for sale soon; unfortunately, she lacks money to purchase food. She would like to request a loan of US $300 to purchase pig food. Lorng's husband is in the picture because Lorng is unavailable.

loans.use: Purchasing pig food

loans.name: Atokhon

texts.en:
Atokhon M. is 36 years old. He lives in Isfara town; he is married and has three children. His wife is a housekeeper. Atokhon processes and sells dried apricots in the local central market. He is experienced in the business of making dried apricots. As a rule he purchases dried apricots in the market and processes them himself.

Because he buys dried apricots wholesale, his prices are lower than regular market prices. He offers a wide assortment of goods for customers of different means. All this allows Atokhon to make his business quite successful and it brings in stable income for the family.

Today Atokhon is requesting 1500 Somoni (450 USD) for a term of 8 months. He is going to spend the loan to purchase more dried fruit to process and sell. He would like to increase his income and give his children a good education. Atokhon expresses his gratitude to everyone supporting him.

loans.use: Increasing of the range of goods to expand his business

loans.name: Art

texts.en:
Art S., 28, is married with three children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 2008, she has been raising pigs to earn a living and is able to make about US$2 of profit per day. 

Her husband is a taxi driver (Phnom Penh- Kampong Cham). Normally, he makes around US$3 of profit per day. Her husband states some problems that he faces in running his business such as: the gas has skyrocketed and passengers have no will to pay more even though they know the gas price is high. That is why he makes less profit to support the family. 

Mrs. Art is asking for a loan to add to her livestock.

loans.use: To expand her livestock, raising pigs.

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en:
Chhin S., 38, is a true entrepreneur who lives with three of her children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 

She has a business selling rice noodles, or what we call in Cambodia's language "Nom Banchok". It is one of the favorite foods among Cambodian people. Rice noodles are served with mint, banana blossoms, string beans, English cucumber, mung bean sprouts and other vegetables. Moreover, they are used in two types of soup: green and red soup. Green soup is cooked with boneless fish only and called in Cambodian "Nom Banchok Samlah Khmer". The other soup can be cooked with pork or chicken and is called "Nom Banchok Namya". On average, she makes $2.50 of profit per day. Her husband is a wedding chef and is able to make $2.50 as well.

Mrs. Chhin would like a loan from Kiva to raise pigs for additional profit to support her family. She sees this as a good opportunity to better her family's standard of living.

loans.use: She wants to raise pigs.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina M. is a hardworking and responsible woman, with a 5-year-old daughter. A year ago, because of difficult family living conditions, her husband went to Russia to earn money since for a long time he couldn’t find a job in his country.

Since she no longer has his support, Madina decided to start her own business to provide for her family. Ever since then, she has been selling Tajik national dresses for women. These activities have also permitted her to make time available to be with her children. Life hasn't been easy for Madina, as she now carries the responsibility for her family alone, but her love for her children motivates her to get ahead.

To increase her sales, Madina is requesting a loan of 3400 Somoni (1000 USD), which she will use to buy merchandise that is on sale, which she will be able to sell at a special price to her customers. This will allow her to grow her customer base. She plans to repay the money in 8 months.

You can be an important part of Madina's accomplishments. She needs your help to grow her business and improve the quality of living for her child.

loans.use: Purchasing Tajik national dresses for women for re-sale

loans.name: Zikriddin

texts.en:
Zikriddin N. is 43 years old. He is married with three children. Zikriddin raises and sells cattle. He purchases the young cattle in the central market, feeds them and then re-sells them at higher prices in the local market. Being in this business for 3 years, he knows very well how to choose the animals and how to breed them and look after them.

Thus, he gets up every morning at five o’clock in order to feed the animals and to look after them. His knowledge and skills allow him to make his business successful and generate a stable and considerable income for his large family.

Zikriddin has already been provided with a loan by IMON and has shown himself to be a responsible borrower with a positive credit history. Today, knowing that the prices for animals are not so high now, but will increase for sure, Zikriddin is planning to enlarge his herd and purchase cows and calves. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting 1000 US Dollars for a term of 12 months. You could become an important part in Zikriddin's family's life. He deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: Purchasing cows and calves to expand his business

loans.name: Mwanamkuu's Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Mwanamkuu is 30 years old. She is married with 3 children, ages 2, 4, and 3. She also takes care of 2 other children, ages 6 and 8. She became a food seller in 2004. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Mwanamkuu now requests a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Time, who also has her own shop.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her stock

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
Mahbuba R. 47 years old. She is married and uses all the money she makes to care for her four children and provide for their education. Mahbuba has an experience of 13 years preparing and selling dried apricots. Mahbuba always makes very productive use of her capital, adding inventory to her supply in a way that allows her to meet her customers' needs. She is also very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her.

Because her business is doing so well, she is increasing her net worth month by month. Mahbuba has been an active and strongly motivated client of IMON since 2005. Her credit history makes her eligible to receive new and larger loans. Today Mahbuba is requesting 1200 USD for a term of 3 months. She is going to spend the loan purchasing dried apricots with the purpose of processing them in order increase the range of her merchandise. With your help this will be possible. Mahbuba expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her and promises to repay her loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: Purchasing dried apricots for processing and re-sale

loans.name: Doem

texts.en: This is the second time Mr. Doem O. has taken a loan in order to improve his living conditions. He is a fisherman in Preak Svay Village in Kandal Province. He is a 39-year-old widower with three children who are all attending the local school. Since his family is in poor conditions, Mr. Doem O. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets for breeding in order to meet the needs of his family. Previously, Mr. Doem O. obtained a loan to buy fish nets for his current business. He has fully paid it back.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Art

texts.en:
Art I., 34, is a former porridge seller. But now she stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her family members. 

Her husband, Neang Yat, has a business as a motor-taxi driver and on average he makes $2.50 of profit per day. This couple has two children and both of them are too young to attend school. 

Mrs. Art is asking for a loan to restart her business by raising animals.

loans.use: She needs to breed pigs.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mahfuza

texts.en:
Mahfuza R. is 31 years old. She is married with two children. She began her business to support her family and aging parents. She learned to process dried fruits and clingstone apricots ten years ago. Since she started her business, her professional growth and development have consistently been supported through IMON’s micro-finance program. Mahfuza has repaid each loan faithfully and fully.

Mahfuza has a large and friendly family who are always trying to help each other. Thus her children and parents help Mahfuza with her business. Now her business is running successfully and it brings considerable income for her family. Today she is requesting a loan of 3400 Somoni (1000 USD) for the term of 7 months to purchase more dried fruits due to great demand from her customers. Mahfuza and her friendly family sincerely thank you for your support.

loans.use: Purchasing dried fruits for processing and re-sale

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
This is the second time that Mrs. Sam S. A. has asked for a loan to improve her business. She is a pig breeder in Dei Edth Kaoh Phos Village in Kandal Province. In her business, Mrs. Sam S. A. raises pigs under the house and it is very difficult for her to look after her pigs.

Thus, Mrs. Sam S. A. decided to ask for a loan to buy cement and brick in order to build a piggery. Her husband, Mr. Tith Chanreaksmey, is a jewelry maker who melts gold to make jewelry. Mrs. Sam S. A. is 43 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom owns a small jewelry store in the local market while three others are attending school. The youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is only four. Mrs. Sam S. A.'s husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy cement and brick in order to build a piggery

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Vann M., 49, is a cucumber farmer who lives with six children. Living in the Kampong Cham province, she is able to earn around $1 of profit per day and is aided by her children, who work as garment factory workers. 

Her husband is a rice farmer and the income he collects annually is just enough for the family. Mrs. Vann is requesting a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $300 to purchase a cow to plow the farmland.

loans.use: To purchase cow to plow the farmland.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi: Trước khi tham gia Qũy tình thương, cửa hàng của chị H. chỉ là một cửa hàng nhỏ chủ yếu phục vụ khách quen và những người xung quanh. Năm 2003 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương vay mức 2.000.000đ để mua thêm một số mỹ phẩm và trang thiết bị cho cửa hàng nhờ vậy khách hàng đến cửa hàng của chị ngày một đông, thu nhập của chị được nâng lên từ 70.000đ - 100.000đ /ngày. Trải qua 5năm vay vốn chị luôn sử dụng vốn  tập trung cho mua sắm, nâng cấp trang thiết bị cho cửa hàng. Đặc biệt, chị đã tham gia lớp đào tạo về trang điểm để tư vấn thêm cho khách hàng khi mua mỹ phẩm. Hiện tại,cửa hàng của chị khang trang và tấp nập nhất nhì khu phố Để đáp ứng tốt nhu cầu của khách hàng chị phải thuê thêm 1 người làm thường xuyên với mức lương 1.000.000đ/tháng, trong dịp cuối năm chị phải thuê thêm 2 người để bán hàng. Thu nhập bình quân của cửa hàng  là 5.000.000/tháng. Chị mong muốn được  vay 17.000.000đ để mua thêm các loại mỹ phẩm cao cấp và trang thiết bị hiện đại để  có thể phục vụ khách hàng một cách tốt nhất.
texts.en:
Mrs. H. joined TYM Fund in 2003. In the first round of loan, she borrowed 2.000.000 VND to purchase cosmetic products and equipment for her salon. Before joining TYM, her shop was small; customers were often acquaintances. But since she invested more in her salon with the help of TYM, it has become increasingly popular, helping her earn about 70.000 to 100.000 per day. For the past 5 years, Mrs. H. has been using loans from TYM Fund to purchase new equipment, enhancing the quality of her salon. She also attended a make-up course, so she can give advice to her customers. As a result, her salon is now one of the best in her area. Now, Mrs. H. has to hire one employee to help her with all the work, with a salary of 1.000.000 VND per month. At the end of the year in particular, she has to hire 2 persons to assist her. Mrs. H.’s monthly income is 5.000.000 VND. In the next round of loan, she would like to borrow 17.000.000 VND ($1025) to purchase more high-quality cosmetic products and modern equipment for her salon to attract more customers.

Translated from Vietnamese by KH. Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: business

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr: Adjo G. est âgée de 34 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle tient le commerce des ustensiles de cuisine  à Danyi, un village situé à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle  souhaite par ce premier crédit de FECECAV accroître la taille de son activité pour attirer beaucoup plus de clientèle et dégager plus de bénéfice. Ce faisant elle contribuera à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille.
texts.en:
At 34, Adjo G. is married and the mother of three children. She owns a business selling kitchen utensils in Danyi, a village about 170 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. With this, her first loan from FECECAV, she hopes to increase the size of her business to draw in more clients and turn greater profits. In so doing, she will contribute to a better quality of life for her family.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of dishes, bowls, and pans for resale

loans.name: Mwajuma's Tushikamane Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 51 years old. She is married with 7 children, aged between 25 and 13. She has been a charcoal, firewood, and spice seller since 1995. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $120 from her sales.

Mwajuma now requests a loan to improve her business by increasing her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Zema.

loans.use: To improve her business by increasing her current stock

loans.name: Eam

texts.en:
Eam H., 64, is a rice farmer who lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1980, she and her husband, Tim Pet, have been growing rice to earn a living and are able to make around $1 of profit per day. 

This couple has nine children and they live with one of their children. All the children who no longer stay at home are employed at different jobs.

Mrs. Eam would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $1,000 to plant rubber trees.

loans.use: She wants to plant rubber trees.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ngo Thi Thu

texts.vi:
Năm 1998 anh chị xây dựng gia đình và được bố mẹ cho ra ở riêng, kinh tế rất khó khăn.Năm 2004 chồng chị không may bị tai nạn và qua đời nên hoàn cảnh gia đình càng khó khăn hơn.
Năm 2000 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và vay mức vốn 700.000 đồng, chị đã sử dụng để mua một số dụng cụ phục vụ cho việc cắt tóc gội đầu. Sau 8 năm tham vay vốn và đầu tư nâng cao tay nghề hiện nay chị đã có cửa hàng khang trang tại trung tâm thôn với lượng khách ngày càng đông. Bên cạnh đó chị còn bán mỹ phẩm phục vụ nhu cầu làm đẹp của chị em phụ nữ tại địa phương. Với thu nhập  bình quân 3.000.000đồng / tháng, cuộc sống của gia đình chị đang được cải thiện từng ngày. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 16.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư vào cửa hàng.
texts.en:
Mrs H. was married in 1998 so she moved out of her parents house with her husband. It was difficult time for them finance wise. In 2004, her husband passed away. She joined TYM fund in 2000. Her first loan was 700.000 VND which was used to buy products for her hair salon. After 8 years and numerous loans later, she now owns a nice hair salon located in the heart of the town. She has built a solid base of clientele. She also sells beauty products due to increasing demand from the locals who are starting to consume this kind of product. On average, her income is 3.000.000 VNDS a month. Her family living condition improves everyday. This time she is requesting 15.000.000 VND to continue investing in her beauty salon.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Chika

texts.en:
Chika I. is 35 years old and single and he lives in Uromi, Edo State, Nigeria. He is a commercial motorcyclist. He has been in this business since 2003. He is a LAPO client.

Chika I. needs the loan amount of US$ 600 to buy another motorcycle, which he will use to convey goods and his customers from one location to another. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy another motorcycle for commercial purposes

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 32 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 18 and 8. She has been an artist and porridge seller since 2000. Every day she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

Mwajuma now requests a loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Chin Thi

texts.vi: Năm 1994 chị Chín tham gia  Quỹ Tình Thương và được vay 300.000 đồng.  Với số vốn này  chị đã đầu tư mua được 100 con gà và ngan về chăn nuôi. Vạn sự khởi đầu nan, từ 100 con gia cầm ban đầu đó sau 6 tháng anh chị đã thu được cả gốc lẫn lãi 2.800.000 đồng, thấy hiệu quả kinh tế cao anh chị lại tiếp tục vay thêm vốn mua gà, ngan với số lượng nhiều hơn, chăn nuôi ngày một phát triển, kinh tế gia đình ngày càng ổn định. Anh Tiến chồng chị là một người đàn ông  tháo vát tính toán làm ăn giỏi, chịu khó học hỏi kinh  nghiệm làm ăn, với số tiền tiết kiệm của gia đình và nguồn vốn vay của Quỹ, năm 2001 anh chị mạnh dạn chuyển đổi đất làm ruộng sang làm kinh tế theo mô hình trang trại để chăn nuôi lợn, gà , vịt, làm cây cảnh. Hiện trang trại của chị có hàng ngàn con gia cầm và hàng trăm loại cây cảnh có giá trị cao, riêng loại cau vua có hơn 100 cây. Ngoài ra chị còn trồng các loại rau quả cung cấp cho nhân dân trong vùng. Hàng tháng thu nhập từ trang trại của gia đình chị từ 5-7 triệu đồng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 19.000.000đ để đầu tư vào trang trại.
texts.en:
In 1994, Mrs. Chin joined the TYM fund and borrowed 300,000 Vietnamese Dong. She used this money to buy 100 poultries to raise. 6 months later, she made a profit of 2800 Vietnamese Dong. Acknowledging the high return, the couple kept borrowing money and bought poultry in larger numbers. The business flourished, and the family’s financial situation gradually became stable. Mr. Tien, her husband, is a skillful and curious man. He spent time studying business. In 2001, when the family’s savings had accumulated, the couple started to build a modern farm on their old fields. They raised chickens, ducks, and pigs. They also planted bonsai. Soon enough, there were thousands of poultries on the farm and hundreds of valuable bonsai. A select 100 of these bonsai were of the Cau Vua type, a particularly valuable tree in Vietnam. They also planted vegetables to deliver to the local market. The family’s income is from 5,000,000 to 7,000,000 Vietnamese Dong per month. She plans to make the next loan of 19,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to invest in the new farm.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: investing in farming

loans.name: Seang

texts.en:
Seang M., 58, is a rice farmer who lives with one of her four children. Living in Kampong Cham province, she is able to make $1 per day and is aided by her children, who work as garment factory workers. 

Her husband, Phon Phan, 57, has had a business collecting recyclable items since 2007. She told a loan officer that her husband earns little because in her village there are many people who have the same business as her husband. On average, her husband makes $3 of profit per day. 

Mrs. Seang is asking for a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport the recyclable items.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport recyclable items.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Salama's Allah Karim Group

texts.en:
Salama is 35 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 18 and 7. She has been a clothing seller since 2004. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 9:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

Salama now requests a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Halima, who has a business of selling food, fruits, and vegetables.

loans.use: To improve her business by inreasing her stock

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok A., 42, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 

Since 1980, she and her husband, Touch Seng, 60, have been working on their farmland growing rice to earn a living, and they are able to make around $1 per day. This couple has eight children, two are employed as garment workers and six others are students. 

Mrs. Sok would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $400 to breed a heifer for a baby cow.

loans.use: To breed a heifer for a baby cow.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Năm 1997 chị Hậu tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và được vay vốn vòng một với số tiền là 700.000 đồng. Với số tiền này  chị đã sử dụng để mua trứng vịt bán tại chợ và nhập hàng cho các quán ăn sáng  thu nhập hàng ngày cũng đủ chi tiêu trong gia đình. Những năm tiếp theo chị đều vay mức cao và buôn bán với số lượng lớn. Đến năm 2000 cùng với nguồn vốn tự có của gia đình anh chị  mua đất làm nhà tạm để xây lò ấp trứng vịt lộn. Nguồn hàng của chị  vừa bán ở chợ , vừa giao hàng cho các quán ăn , nhà hàng. Qua hơn 10 năm vay vốn và sử dụng rất hiệu quả  kinh tế gia đình chị ngày một phát triển. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang có  2 máy ấp trứng vịt lộn và mỗi tuần xuất 40.000 quả trứng vịt lộn cho các quán ăn , nhà hàng , ngoài ra còn bán lẻ cho bà con trong thôn. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 19.000.000 để tiếp tục đầu tư vào kinh doanh trứng vịt lộn.
Thu nhập bình quân 8.000.000 đồng / tháng
texts.en:
In 1997, Ms. H. became a member of this organization and was able to obtain her first loan of $700.00usd. She used this money to invest in buying duck eggs, selling them at the local market and in bulk to restaurants. The profit made daily was just enough to cover her family expenses. The following years, she has been obtaining larger loans to increase the volume of her business. In 2000, she was able to use the money she made to purchase a piece of land to build ducks houses for nesting and laying eggs. Her inventory was enough to sell to the local market, eateries and restaurants. After 10 plus years of borrowing along with smart investment, she has seen a success and growth with her business. Presently, she has 2 egg warmers that produces 40.000 duck eggs a week, which she use to cater to eateries, restaurants and to the locals in her village. This next loan, she is requesting 19.000.000 in which she plans to use for her business. Her average income is 8.000.000d/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Asatira

texts.en:
Asatira is 36 years old. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 15 and 5 years old. She has been a clothes seller since 2003. Everyday she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Now Asatira is looking for a loan to buy more clothes for re-sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for re-sale.

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en:
Khiev N., 61, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 

She and her husband have been working on their farmland growing rice to earn a living, and they are able to make around $1 per day. They live with five of their eight children. Every month, their children always support them by sending around $50 to support the family. 

Mrs. Khiev N. would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $500 to purchase a horse and horse cart to transport passengers or goods for profit. She told a loan officer that in the future, she will run a grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and horse cart to transport passengers or goods for profit.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị Liên chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt,Năm 1995 chị đã bàn với chồng tham gia Quỹ tình thương để vay vốn mở rộng chăn nuôi. Với  mức vốn đầu tiên là 300.000đ, anh chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và giành một phần vốn để chồng chị mua phụ tùng mở quán sửa chữa xe đạp. Từ chăn nuôi và sửa xe đạp anh chị thu nhập của gia đình đã được cải thiện hơn với mức400.000đ/ tháng. Đến năm 2000, sau 5 năm vừa làm vừa tích lũy kinh nghiệm nhận thấy nhu cầu, đời sống của  nhân dân ngày một tăng lên  anh chị đã chuyển từ  kinh doanh, sửa chữa xe đạp sang kinh doanh bán hàng ăn uống. Cửa hàng của anh chị rất có uy tín trong vùng nên luôn luôn đông khách. Hiện tại anh chị đang thuê  02 công nhân phục vụ tại cửa hàng với mức lương mỗi tháng 1.500.000đ/người. Năm 2004 anh chị đã cải thiện nâng cấp của hàng của anh chị từ quán nhỏ nhà hàng khang trang có thể  phục vụ khách được 100 khách cùng một lúc. Hiện nay anh chị mong muốn được vay thêm vốn để tiếp tục đầu tư mua thực phẩm, đồ uống để phục vụ khách hàng.
Mức vốn xin vay : 19.000.000đ
thu nhập của gia đình bình quân 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Before becoming a member of this organization, Ms. L. depended on raising livestock and providing child daycare services as a source of income for her family. In 1995, she and her husband had decided to join the organization to help expand her business of raising farm animals. Her first loan was 300.000d, in which she use as capital for her farm animals and a portion of the money her husband had used to purchased equipments to repair bicycles. Between the two businesses of raising farm animals and repairing bicycles, her family income has rose averaging 400.000d/month. Then in 2000, after 5 years of business experiences, the couple switch over to the restaurant business after seeing a rise in their community economy. Their restaurant has been a popular eatery and always filled with customers. Presently, they have 2 employees that help run the restaurant each making 1.500.000d/person. In 2004, they expanded their restaurant from a small eatery to a restaurant that can serve up to 200 customers at a time. Currently, she and her husband are requesting a loan to use as capital for buying food and restaurant supplies. The requested loan is: 19.000.000d. Her average income is about 6.000.000d/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Nov L. I., 41, is a rice farmer and also raises ducks for eggs. 

She lives with three of her four children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband are working together to earn a living and are able to make around $2.50 of profit per day. All the children are employed in different jobs and always send their parents around $20 each month to support the family. 

Mrs. Nov would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $800 to purchase more mechanic tools for one of her sons who works as motorbike repairer.

loans.use: To purchase more tools for one of her sons who works as motorbike repairer.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Cũng giống như bao người phụ nữ nông thôn khác sau khi xây dựng gia đình thu nhập của gia đình chị Nghiên chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt. Tuy phải lao động rất vất vả nhưng cuộc sống gia đình chị vẫn gặp rất nhiều khó khăn. Năm 1994 chị Nghiên  tham gia vào quỹ để vay vốn phát triển kinh tế gia. Ban đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư cho chăn nuôi nhưng đến năm 2008 chị mạnh dạn  chuyển đổi ngành nghề từ chăn nuôi chuyển sang  mua 2 máy may và nhận hàng làm thuê cho các cơ sở. Vốn là người phụ nữ khéo tay chị còn mua thêm vải về cắt may bán hàng cho các quầy hàng tại chợ huyện và nhận may quần áo cho bà con địa phương.Hàng tháng thu nhập của gia đình chị từ chăn nuôi, may mặc  4 đến 5 triệu đồng .Sau một thời gian vay vốn làm ăn, kinh tế gia đình chị đến nay rất ổn định, chị đã xây được ngôi nhà 2 tầng  rất khang trang với diện tích 80m2  và mua sắm được một số tiện nghi có giá trị .
Chị  muốn vay 19.000.000 đ để mua thêm máy may và mở xưởng sản xuất.
texts.en:
Just like a lot of young women after having a family, Ms. N. depended on raising livestock and providing child care as a source of income for her family. She worked hard to provide for her family, but she was unable to see the income coming in through her hard work. In 1994, Ms. N. joins this organization in hope to better her family financially. In the beginning, she was able to borrow and use the loan to invest in raising farm animals. But in 2008, she got the courage to switch business from raising livestock to purchasing 2 sewing machines and started accepting workloads from several companies. Ms. N. is a very skilled with her hands. In addition to her work, she buys fabric to make pieces of clothing to sell in the local market. She also offers tailoring services to the people in her village. The family monthly income between raising farm animals and her sewing works average in about 4 to 5.000.000d/month. After a period of borrowing and investing, the family financial status has improved and since been stable. She was able to build a 2 story home, furnishing it with quality items that have values. She is requesting a loan of 19.000.000d to buy more sewing machines and capital for a convenient store business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Te

texts.en:
Te Y., 58, is a housewife who stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her family members.

Her husband works digging wells (pumping wells) to earn a living and is able to make $10 of profit per day. This couple also has support from their children of about $50 per month. 

To make more profit to support the family, Mrs. Te would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to purchase a grinding mill to offer that service to the local people for extra profit. She hopes the grinding mill will double the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill to offer that service to the local people.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mai Thi

texts.vi: Là một gia đình thuần nông nên thu nhập của gia đình chị Mai chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt. Để kinh tế gia đình bớt khó khăn hơn anh chị đã phải làm rất nhiều nghề  để kiếm sống, từ buôn bán nhỏ đến mở cửa hàng bán đồ ăn sáng như cháo, xôi, bánh mỳ.Năm 2005 chị tham gia vào quỹ để được vay vốn phát triển kinh tế . Vòng đầu tiên chị xin vay 3.000.000 đồng chị đã mua ếch giống về chăn nuôi tại ao của gia đình, đồng thời chị còn nuôi thêm cá. Ngoài việc đầu tư chăn nuôi ếch và cá gia đình chị vẫn tiếp tục làm đồ ăn sáng phục vụ bà con. Hiện nay gia đình chị đang nuôi 5 lồng ếch thịt cứ 3 tháng cho thu hoạch một lần. Nhờ biết cách sử dụng vốn vay hiệu quả kinh tế gia đình chị Mai đã có sự thay đổi rõ rệt  thu nhập  của gia đình luôn ổn định  với mức bình quân 3.500.000 đồng /tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để mua ếch giống và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
As Mrs. Mai’s family is a traditional agrarian one, their income comes solely from live-stock and planting using traditional farming methods. In order to improve their living conditions, the couple has been trying a variety of jobs, ranging from small retail to breakfast food service. In 2005, she joined the TYM fund and was able to borrow 3,000,000 Vietnamese Dong. She bought frogs and fish to breed and raise in the pond in her yard. In addition, she continues to serve breakfast to local customers. At the moment, her family is taking care of 5 frog stalls, which can be harvested every 3 months. She managed to improve the family’s living conditions through clever use of its money. The family’s income is now stable at 3,500,000 Vietnamese Dong per month. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy more frogs and food for them.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: livestock

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum T., 53, is a true entrepreneur who lives with two of her three children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. 

She owns a plot of land for growing rice and also sells fish at an open air market to earn approximately $2.50 of profit per day. Her husband, Chrang Theng, 64, has a business catching fish. He provides his catch to his wife and also sells in the market as well. On average, he makes around $1 of profit per day. 

Mrs. Sum would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $800 to purchase more fishing tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing tools for her husband.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sin

texts.en:
Sin S., 64, is married and lives with her husband. Living in Kampong Cham province, she and her husband, Kang Pech, 64, are rice farmers and are able to make around $1 of profit per day. 

This couple has three children, one is a goldsmith and two are garment workers. As the goldsmith's business is growing, Mrs. Sin would like a loan from Kiva to purchase more goldsmithing tools for her son.
(Mr. Kang Pech is pictured because his wife was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more goldsmithing tools for her son.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Pok

texts.en: Mr. Pok P. is a villager in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province. He is a motorbike taxi driver who can only make a meager income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Khiev Nara, is employed in a garment factory. Even though Mr. Pok P. and his wife have different businesses, they still cannot afford to fix up their house so Mr. Pok P. decided to ask for a loan for his purpose. Mr. Pok P. is 27 years old and the father of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is only five. His wife is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: to repair his house

loans.name: Barice's Muamini Mungu Group

texts.en:
Barice is 48 years old. She is married with 6 children aged between 22 and 4 years old. She has been a mobile and food seller since 2001. Every day, she works from 7am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Barice is now looking for a loan to buy more commodities to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Khadija, who also has business of selling mobile and food.

loans.use: To buy more commodities to improve her business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Ms. Sok C. T. is a villager in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province. She decided to ask for a loan because she wants to repair her house. She is a vegetable seller who can earn a little income to support her whole family. Her husband’s name is Hell Phallar. He assists his wife with her business. They have five children to support for both their living and studying.  Ms. Sok C. T. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to fix the house.

loans.name: Hosn

texts.en:
Hosn lives in Burj Barajneh, a suburban area of Beirut where, as a mother of five children, she started tailoring as a hobby. When her husband lost his job during the civil war, she decided to offer her tailoring services to customers while at home. In 2000, she received her first micro loan to buy a sewing machine, the first of several improvements in both her business and family life.  Over the years as she expanded her activity, Hosn managed to help her husband buy a car to work as a taxi driver and send her children to school. 

"Oum Walid", as everybody calls her, possesses a welcoming smile that has made her well known in the neighborhood. Today, she wishes to expand her home-based business and plans to use this new loan to buy inventory and perhaps rent a small shop that would make her more accessible to her clients.

loans.use: To buy goods for her business

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate O. operates a restaurant and serves a variety of Ghanaian local dishes such as Fufu (made out of cassava), Omo-tuo (made out of rice), and other kinds of food at Yammoransah on the Cape Coast. Kate has received a junior high education, is married and has 5 children. Her husband is an administrator. Kate has been operating this restaurant since 2003. She is responsible for the children's school fees, food, and clothing, as well as the utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more rice, cassava, fish, and other ingredients she needs to prepare the food for her restaurant. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to provide a quality education for the children.

loans.use: To buy more rice, cassava, fish, and other ingredients

loans.name: Lom

texts.en:
Mrs. Lom K., who is 41 years old, is pig raiser; additionally, she distills alcohol for sale. Her husband, Mr. Poch Yuk, who is 42 years old, has a milling machine; he charges service from people who come to grind rice. Lom has four children, one of whom is married and another of whom helps Lom raise pigs. The others live at home and go to school.

To increase her family's income, Lom would like to request a loan to purchase rice to grind for sale. The remainder of loan will be used to purchase more piglets to raise. She hopes that the loan will allow her to expand her business and increase her family's income. Lom's husband is pictured because Lom was unavailable.

loans.use: Purchasing rice to grind and more piglets to raise

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys A. is married and has 4 children. Gladys sells maize, beans and other food items at Yammoransah on the Cape Coast, which she has done since 1981. Her husband is a farmer. Gladys uses her income to pay for the children's school fees, food, and clothing, as well as the utility bills. Gladys will use the loan to purchase more maize, beans and other food items from the farmers to be sold at the market. With the new profits from her expanded business, Gladys plans to expand her capital base.

loans.use: To purchase more maize, beans and other food items

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam, a 48-year-old widow living in Laylaki, a suburban area of Beirut, is a home-based hairdresser who started the business to provide for her three children after the passing of her husband. Over the years, thanks to her business income, she has been able to meet her children's schooling needs and today her daughter is a university student.  

In 2003, she took out her first micro loan in order to expand her business through the purchase of accessories and cosmetics. Mariam is now requesting a $600 loan to buy more goods and continue developing her business.

loans.use: To buy goods for her business

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Philomina Y. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Philomina sells Gamrole (made of flour) on the Cape Coast, which she has done since 2005. Philomina uses her income to pay for school fees, and food for the family. Philomina will use the loan to purchase more ingredients like margarine, flour and other ingredients for the Gamrole. With the new profits from her expanded business, Philomina plans to assist her husband in building a family house.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients like margarine and flour to make Gamrole.

loans.name: Farida's Tushikamane Group

texts.en:
Farida is 49 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 26 and 19. She runs her own shop, and she has been a clothing seller since 1999. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Farida now hopes for a loan to buy more items to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Teresia, who also has a business dealing with clothing sales.

loans.use: To buy more items to improve her business

loans.name: Saada's Nia Njema Group

texts.en:
Saada is 36 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 13 and 7. She has been a charcoal and juice seller since 2003. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 9:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Saada now requests a loan to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Suzana and Salama, who have businesses selling used clothes, snacks, and juice.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy A. sells maize, beans, and other food items at Yammoransah on the Cape Coast. Mercy has received a junior high education, is married, and has 3 children. Her husband is a carpet dealer. Mercy has been selling maize, beans, and other food items since 1993. She is responsible for paying the school fees and feeding the family. Her loan will be used to buy more maize, beans, and other food items from the farmers to be sold at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to assist her husband in building a family house.

loans.use: To buy more maize, beans, and other food items

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Trước khi tham gia vào quỹ tình thương kinh tế gia đình chị Bảy gặp rất nhiều khó khăn do đông con và thiếu vôn làm ăn. Năm 1994 khi Quỹ tình thương về xã Tiên Dược hoạt động chị đã bàn với chồng tham gia vàp Quỹ để vay vốn phát triển kinh tế gia đình. Với số vốnvay 300000đ ban đầu chị đã sử dụng để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi bước đầu thu nhập của gia đình chị đã được cải thiện hơn. Qua nhiều năm vay vốn của Quỹ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, gà kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển, chị đã xây được một ngôi nhà khang trang và mua sắm được một số tiện nghi trong gia đình. Ngoài ra anh chị còn xây dựng được một khu trang trại để phục vụ cho chăn nuôi lợn giống và gà thịt. Hiện tại chị đang nuôi 40 con lợn thịt và 500 con gà. Chồng chị hiện cũng có một của hàng bán đồ điện tại chợ huyện. Các con chị đều đã có công ăn việc làm ổn định. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 19000000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư vao chăn nuôi và cửa hàng đồ điện. Thu nhập 10000000đ/ tháng
texts.en:
Before joining TYM Fund, Mrs. B.’s family encountered lots of difficulties because of large number of family members and lack of starting fund. In 1994, TYM Fund came to Tien Duoc area and therefore, Mrs. B. talked to her husband and decided to join the Fund. With a starting fund of 20 USD, she used the borrowed money in raising animals, improving her family income. After several years, her family economy has improvements. She is able to build a house and furnish her home. Besides, she and her husband are able to expand their farm to raise pigs and chickens. Currently, she is having 40 pigs and 500 chickens. Her husband also has a electronic shop in the market. Her children are all working. This time, she wants to borrow 1150 USD to invest more in her farm and in her husband’s electronic shop. Her average income is 625 USD/ month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising, business

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao A., who is 30 years old, sells groceries and beef soup in her village; her husband, Mr. Poch Vut, who is 38 years old, sells fish door to door. Mao earns around US $4 per day, and her husband earns around US $3 per day. Lom lives with three children, all of whom are in school and live in the Danrun Commune in the Siem Reap Province. Because of increasing demand and competition, Lom would like to request a loan to purchase more groceries and to decorate her store.

loans.use: Purchasing more groceries and decorating her store

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya is 32 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 10 and 3. She also takes care of 1 other person, age 60. She has been a clothing and shoe seller since 2000. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 9:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Hidaya now requests a loan to buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and clothes for her business

loans.name: Ha Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Hoàn tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương năm 1995. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ hoàn cảnh gia đình chị rất khó khăn do đông con và thu nhập chỉ trông vào đồng ruộng.Vào quỹ chị xin vay 300000đ để mua 2 con lợn giống để nuôi. Sau 4 tháng dự án cho thu nhập  500.000đ. Thấy dự án chăn nuôi có hiệu quả anh chị đã tiếp tục vay thêm vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Năm 2004 chồng chị tham gia lớp tập huấn về chuyển đổi mô hình chăn nuôi theo trang trại, kết thúc khóa học vận dụng những kiến thức đã học được và kinh nghiệm đã được tích lũy anh chị quyết định mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi theo trang trại để phát triển kinh tế gia đình, Sau 4 năm thực hiện dự án hiện tại gia đình chị đang là chủ trang trại khá quy mô với nhiều loại cây ăn quả, 100 con lợn và 1000 con gà. Anh chị mong muốn được vay thêm vốn để đầu tư vào trang trại của gia đình. 
Mức vốn xin vay 19000000đ
texts.en:
Mrs. H. joined the TYM Fund since 1995. Before becoming a member of the Fund, she faced a lot of difficulties because of having many children and her income came mainly from her farming. She borrowed 20 USD to buy 2 pigs. After 4 months of membership, she earned 40 USD. Seeing that her project was productive, she decided to borrow more to invest in raising animals. In 2004, her husband joined the class about farming and farming projects. After the course, he applied his knowledge and expanded the farm to improve family economy. After 4 years of operation, Mrs. H. and her husband is having a well-equipped farm with a variety of plants, 100 pigs and 1000 chickens. This time, she and her husband want to borrow 1150 USD to invest more in the farm.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Wahida

texts.en:
Wahida is 37 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 13 and 5. She has been a food seller since 2003. Every day she works from 6:00 AM to 4:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Wahida now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya is 32 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 10 and 3. She also takes care of 1 other person, age 60. She has been a clothing and shoe seller since 2000. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Hidaya now requests a loan to buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and clothes for her business

loans.name: Asha's Kujikwaa Si Kuanguka Group

texts.en:
Asha is 26 years old. She is married with 2 children ages 6 and 3 years old. She has been a food seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Salma, who has a business dealing with clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items to improve her business

loans.name: Raya's Wanawake Na Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Raya is 32 years old. She is married with 3 children, aged between 4 and 8. She has been a shoe and perfume seller since 2004. Every day she works from 9:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Raya is now looking for a loan to buy more shoes and perfumes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Nuru, who has a business dealing with chips and snacks sales.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and perfumes for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Memunatu's Group

texts.en: Memunatu T. is the leader of Unity Group, a microfinance collective with four other members: Ramatu M., Isatu M., Mamusu K. and Sally B.. They are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni City and are requesting a loan of $1175, which will enable them increase the sizes of their businesses.  Previous loans have been taken out and repaid by the members of Unity Group.  Memunatu herself, however, was born in Makeni City 30 years ago and is married to a truck driver.  They have three children, all of whom go to school.  Memunatu has been working in the firewood business for over five years, and sells wood to her neighbours for a marginal profit, which she uses to feed and clothe her family.  Now she is hoping, along with her colleagues, to expand her business with a new loan.

loans.use: Expand on their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Saroun

texts.en: Saroun N., who is 27 years old, raises pigs; additionally, she distills alcohol for sale. Her husband is a construction worker. It takes 3 to 4 months to raise the pigs before selling them to butchers. During that time, Saroun uses the sale of alcohol to supplement her family's income. She works hard for her family and cares for two children, all of whom are too young to work. In order to expand her pig raising business, she would like to request a loan to purchase more piglets to raise. The remainder of the loan would be used to purchase wine materials. Saroun's husband is pictured because Saroun is unavailable.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise and wine materials

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey C., 40, is married and lives with her children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 

Since 2000, she has been selling fruits in the market to earn a living and is able to make US$6.50 a day and is aided by her children who work as garment factory workers. Her husband, 41, has a small restaurant selling many kinds of meat, beer and wine. On average, he makes $2.50 of profit per day. This couple has five children, two are garment workers,  two work collecting recyclable items and the last one is a student. 

Mrs. Srey would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of US$600 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer to transport the fruits to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike with a trailer to transport the fruits to the market.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sadija

texts.en: Sadija is a 51-year-old married woman. She lives with her two children, 22 and 24 years old, and her husband in Banovići. She sells clothes, and she requested this loan in the amount of 600 KM ($US450) to purchase more clothes for selling. She is satisfied with her income from her business and wants to maintain this income by expanding her offerings and so help her household with money.

loans.use: To buy more clothes.

loans.name: Elvedina

texts.en:
Elvedina is a married woman from the town Banovići. Her husband has a full-time job and earns about 800 KM monthly. They have one child.

Elvedina works as a supervisor in a furniture factory. This loan in the amount of 1200 KM is her first and Elvedina will use it to buy clothes on wholesale. She will sell them retail in order to earn more money for her household.

Elvedina also does the crochet and sells crochet products.

loans.use: To buy clothes.

loans.name: Self Help Group

texts.en:
This group is called Self Help. Its members include: Alie F., Amanita K. and Isatu S.. They are all business people in Makeni. They have been receiving loans from SMT for more than 2 years now.

Through these loans they get from SMT, these entrepreneurs are able to remain in business and sustain themselves. However, they still need more new loans to enable them enhance their businesses. They are thus requesting a loan of Le 3,000,000.00.

Alie (in the middle) is the leader of the group. He was born in Makeni about 34 years ago. Alie is married and has 1 child. His wife sells slippers, and Alie has sold cosmetics, pastes, toothbrushes, watches, mirrors, ear-rings, radio antennas, and a lot more for the past 6 years now. His previous loans, Alie told me, have enabled him to pay school fees for his junior brothers; feed his parents, junior brothers, wife and child; and pay his house rent. With this new loan, Alie would like to invest in another business such as palm-oil and groundnuts.

loans.use: Expand  their individual businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Nermina

texts.en:
Nermina is from Banovići and she has one child, five years old. She works as a seamstress in a factory that produces clothes.

This is her first loan, in the amount of 1000 KM. With it she wants to buy chickens. Her goal is to fatten them and after that to sell them and earn additional money for her household. Her salary from the factory is not enough because her husband is a seasonal worker.

loans.use: To buy chickens.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith O. sells fruits like mangoes, paw paw, banana, and so on. She has been in this business since 1998. Judith is 47 years old and married with six children and lives in Lagos state.

Judith needs a loan amount of $450 to purchase fruits for sale.

loans.use: To buy fruits for her stall.

loans.name: Tamima

texts.en:
Tamima is 28 years old. She is married with 1 child, age 4. She has been a clothing seller since 2005. Every day she works from 9:30 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Tamima now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina was born in 1979 and she is married with two children. Her husband works as a policeman in the town Lukavac, where they live with their family. She works in her father's household appliance store.

This loan, for 1000 KM ($US750), is Sabina's third with Women for Women International. With it she intends to buy a new cash register for the store because the current one is too old.

loans.use: To buy a cash register.

loans.name: Samira's Mpaji Ni Mungu Group

texts.en:
Samira is 26 years old. She is divorced with 3 children aged between 9 and 4 years old. She has been running her own shop since 1999. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Samira is now requesting a loan to buy more commodities to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Zuwena, who also has a business dealing with shop ownership.

loans.use: To buy more commodities to improve her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Senija

texts.en: Senija was born in 1952 and she is married. She does the agriculture and with this loan she intends to upgrade her greenhouse and to buy a water pump for it in order to ease the work and to improve the yield of her vegetables. This is her second loan, in the amount of 1000 KM ($US750), and she will repay it in 12 months.

loans.use: Upgrading her greenhouse.

loans.name: Dinka

texts.en:
Dinka is from Banovići village. She is married and her husband works in a coal mine, earning about 800 KM monthly. They have one child, six years old.

This is Dinka's first loan at WWI, in the amount of 1000 KM. She wants to start selling used clothes and her big wish is to expand this business and to have something to do while her husband is at work.

loans.use: To buy used clothes.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is 54 years old, married and has 4 children. She lives in Lagos state. Florence sells tomatoes and peppers to her customers. She buys the tomatoes and peppers directly from farmers. She learned this business from her mother while she was growing up. She has been in this business for the past 5 years. Florence needs the loan to buy more tomatoes and peppers to sell. She says "Thank you."

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes for sale

loans.name: Sedina

texts.en: Sedina is a divorced woman from a place called Čubrić, near the town Banovići. She receives support for her two sons, 12 and 19, in the amount of 280 KM. Sedina will use this first loan at Women for Women International, in the amount of 1400 KM, to buy up more used clothes and to expand her clothing fund. Her wish is to maintain her selling and her income, because this is the only secure source of income for her family.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes.

loans.name: Ajakore

texts.en: Ajakore supplies bags of charcoal to women who cook food on the roadside -- roast yam, plantains, and corn at strategic locations. She also sells to housewives who use firewood for cooking. She has been in this business since 1998. She learned this business from her elder sister. Ajakore is 36 years old and married to Mr. M.. They have three children. She and her family live in Lagos state. Ajakore needs the loan amount of $450 to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Amela

texts.en: Amela is 20 years old and lives with her husband in the town Banovići.  She works as a hairdresser, and she earns about 400 KM. This is her first loan in the amount of 600 KM. Amela will use it to buy new hairdressing tools in order to start her own business at home.  She plans to save the money and use it to open her own hairdressing salon.

loans.use: To buy new hairdressing tools to open her own salon

loans.name: Šaha

texts.en:
Šaha is from village Stupari, near the town Kladanj. She lives with her husband and two children who go to school. Her husband works as a seasonal constructor in Croatia.

Šaha does agriculture and cattle breeding and sells milk and milk products. She can earn about 150 KM monthly.

This is her first loan at Women for Women International, in the amount of 1000 KM ($US750), and she will use it to buy additional hay for her cow. Šaha will need more food for her cow because the winter will be long and her cow will bear a calf at the beginning of the next year.

loans.use: To buy hay.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin O. is 40 years old, married and has three children. For the past eight years, Toyin has been selling Nigerian soup ingredients like dry pepper, crayfish, local seasonings, and melon seeds. She is seeking a loan of $450 to buy more soup ingredients to allow her to expand her customer base. Toyin is very happy with her business but would like to see it grow so she can better provide for her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more soup ingredients for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Hava

texts.en:
Hava is from Rainci, a small village near the town of Kalesija. She is a widow and this is her first loan, in the amount of 1200 KM ($US875).

Hava will use the loan to buy more chickens for fattening, because she already has soM.. Her wish is to expand this business during the winter, because she can earn more money by selling them at this tiM. than in spring or summer.

loans.use: To buy more chickens.

loans.name: Sina's Yarabi Tupe Salama Group

texts.en:
Sina is 26 years. She is married with two children aged six and three. Sina has owned her own cafe since 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Sina now requests for a loan to buy more items for her cafe. She will share this loan with her sub-group member, Sharifa, who also has business dealing with her own shop.

loans.use: To buy more items for her cafe.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza is 30 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 6 and 4 years old. She has been a food seller since 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Aziza is now looking for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Šerifa

texts.en:
Šerifa is a 52-year-old widow who lives with her two children in the village Rainci, near the town Kalesija. She does the agriculture and sells vegetables that she plants.

This loan in the amount of 600 KM ($US450) she will use to buy chicken for fattening in order to sell them and to use that money for her children and their school. Business with chicken is safer than with vegetables during the winter and she hopes that she will improve her household incoM. until the spring when she will again start with sowing vegetables.

loans.use: To buy chicken.

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: Kehinde is 31 years old and married with three children. She lives in Lagos state with her family. Kehinde sells tinned tomato paste and seasoning. Kehinde also sells adults' and children's slippers. She has been in this business since 2001. She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more tins of tomato paste and seasonings.

loans.use: To buy more tinned tomato paste for sale

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.en:
Zuhra is a 31-year-old woman, the mother of two children. She lives with her family in the town Banovići. In her current business, she does the agriculture while her husband works in Slovenija.

Zuhra has requested a loan in the amount of 800 KM ($US600). This is her first loan and she is asking for it because she wants to buy chicken for fattening. Her business with selling vegetables has been successful so far and she can earn up to 300 KM per month. Her wish is to expand the business with chicken during the winter. She hopes to increase her income through this loan, and thinks that this purchase will help her with money during the winter.

loans.use: To buy chicken.

loans.name: Feyisayo

texts.en: Feyisayo is 30 years old and married with two children. She is a tailor and has been in this business for the past eight years. She started her own business in the year 2000. Feyisayo lives with her family in Lagos state. She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy different kinds of weaving thread. She says thank you.

loans.use: Purchase of weaving threads

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a client of LAPO (Life Above Poverty Organization). She is 43 years old and married with four lovely children.

Mary is a registered medicine dealer. A nurse by profession, she has retired from service. She has been selling medicine and drinks for a long time.

Mary needs a loan of $450 to purchase more medicine for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine for sale.

loans.name: Maguno

texts.en:
Maguno is 49 years. She is divorced with three children aged between 25 and 18 years old. She has been a tailoring, firewood and khanga (traditional clothing) seller since 1990. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Maguno now requests a loan to improve her business by increasing her inventory.

loans.use: To improve her business by increasing her inventory.

loans.name: Fauzia

texts.en:
Fauzia is 39 years. She is a widow with 3 children between 2 and 8 years old. She has been a food seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 7AM to 6PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Fauzia now seeks a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Oba

texts.en:
Oba styles hair. She also braids it and sells various hair items like hair extensions, hair creams, hair relaxer, and hair treatments. She is happy with her business.

Oba keeps her shop open from 7am to 7pm. She has been in business since 1994. She needs the loan amount of $450 to purchase more hair materials for hair styling. Oba is 43 years old and married to Mr. O. and they have four children. She says thank you.

loans.use: Purchase of hair materials such as hair extensions, hair relaxer, hair cream

loans.name: Ekatte

texts.en: Ekatte has a vegetable farm where she plants many items including pumpkins, waterleafs e.t.c. She has been operating this business for the past five years. She apprenticed with a farmer for over a year. Ekatte works at the farm from 5am-7pm. When her children are on holidays they help her with the farm work. Market women come to her farm to buy vegetables to resell at wholesale and retail. Ekatte is married to Mr. F. and they have four children. She is requesting a loan amount of $450 to buy more vegetable seedlings for planting.

loans.use: Purchase more seedlings for planting

loans.name: Bilikis

texts.en:
Bilikis is a young hard-working mother of two children; she is 33 years old and is married to Mr. S.. Bilikis sells fresh tomatoes and peppers to her customers; she has been in this business for the past eight years. Tomatoes and peppers are used in the preparation of local dishes, so the demand for them is high.

Bilikis started this business in 2000. She needs the loan amount of US$ 450 to buy more tomatoes and peppers for sale. She says thank you.

loans.use: Purchase more tomatoes and peppers

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Toyin sells plastic items of different sizes and shapes. This includes plastic chairs, plates, jugs, spoons, buckets, and bowls. Toyin is a hardworking woman. Her plastics are uniquely arranged in her shop. Her customers are happy with her choice of plastics. She has been in this trade for a long time.

Toyin is 49 years old and she is married to Mr. O.; they have three children. Toyin hopes to train her children up to the university level so that she can be called "mama graduate". Toyin needs the loan amount of $450 to purchase more plastic items for sale. She says plastic business is good for the market.

loans.use: Purchase more plastic items for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kijakazi's Tusivunjane Moyo Group

texts.en:
Kijakazi is 29 years old and married with 3 children, aged 13, 11 and 8. She has been a tailor since 2006. Every day, she works from 8AM to 9pPM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $10 from her sales.

Kijakazi now requests a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Khadija and Salma.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Fumilola

texts.en: Fumilola is 37 years old and she is married with four children. She has been in the business of hair styling for over ten years. Fumilayo sells hair materials like hair extensions, relaxer, and cream. She makes different hairstyles and her customers are happy with them. Her shop is open from 8AM to 7PM. With the steady increase in the number of her customers, she needs the loan amount of $450 to buy one hair dryer and hair materials. She says that this will make her customers patronize her more. She thanks you.

loans.use: Purchase one hair dryer and hair materials like hair extension, hair relaxer, hair cream.for sale.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 40 years old. She is married with 5 children aged between 15 and 7 years old. She has been a clothes seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Rehema is now looking for a loan to buy more clothes for the expansion of her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for the expansion of her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has been selling building materials since 1998. Elizabeth is 37 years old and has five children; she lives in Lagos state with her family. She is happy with her business. Building materials for sale  include cement and blocks. Elizabeth is determined to work hard and assist her husband in supporting their children. 
Elizabeth requests a loan amount of $450 to purchase more building materials to sell; She thanks you.

loans.use: Purchase more building materials for sale

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is 46 years old. She is married with 1 child. She has been a clothes seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Riziki is now looking for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 40 years old and married with four children.  Agnes sells provisions, foodstuffs, and drinks.  She lives in Lagos with her family.  Agnes buys her foodstuffs from Mile 12 in Lagos state, and she brings the foodstuffs to her community to sell.  Agnes sells foodstuffs like rice, beans, and yams.  She has been in this business for the past eighteen years.  She is a client of LAPO (Kiva's Field Partner).  She needs the loan amount of $450 to purchase more foodstuff and drinks to sell.

loans.use: Purchase of more provisions and drinks

loans.name: Kudirat

texts.en:
Kudirat Y. sells drinks in wholesale and retail. Her drinks business is thriving. She has a deep freezer where she cools these drinks for her customers and this has helped her to attract more customers. She needs an additional fund to keep her business thriving, so she is requesting a loan amount of $450 to buy more crates of drinks in order to meet the demands of her customers.

Kudirat is married and has five children; she is 42 years old and she and her family live in Lagos state. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: Purchase more drinks for sale.

loans.name: Yemi

texts.en:
Yemi A. is 40 years old and married with three children. Her eldest child is a graduate while her last child is in a public university. She sells frozen food items like fish, chicken and turkey. She has been in this business for long time. She supplies to women who sell in the open market. In the photo, you see her standing beside the deep freezer.

Yemi needs this loan of $450 to buy more frozen items for sale. She says thank you

loans.use: Purchase more frozen foods

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Success

texts.en: Success O. supplies bags of charcoal to women who cook food on the roadside: roasted yams, plantains and corn. She also supplies charcoal to women who cook food at social functions and also housewives who prefer to use firewood for cooking. She has been in this business since 1997. Success is 46 years old, married and has 4 children. She and her family live in Lagos state. Success needs the loan amount of $450 to purchase more bags of charcoal for sale.

loans.use: Purchase more bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Asha's Twaomba Salama. Group

texts.en:
Asha is 38 years old. She is married with 4 children aged 19, 17, 16 and 8 years old. She has been a food seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.
